reviewText: this shows what SOME but not all churches are all about for real.that would be lying,thieving,manipulating and far far worse.steve martin shows up in kansas and breaks down in a small town[the town is not real.its a movie set]..he uses a tent revival to rip off the unnassuming people here using god as his tool to pry open thier pocketbooks.he,in fact,has nothing to do with god and is evil.he PRETENDS to be a preacher but is a crook.its sad that some people are this way.but its happening..he basicly dances around and knows how to get people feeling good so they dont realize he is a farce.the reality is theres been more people killed in the name of god than for any other reason due to people twisting the word of god to thier own destructive ends.ALTHOUGH I HEAR COMMUNISM HAS Racked up a lot too.this is very wrong..the important message is that there are wolves in sheeps clothing out there.and probably where you least expect it. .steve martin is all down hill anymore.there are only 3 or so good movies left.this one is 3rd of those 3.la story outranks in at 2.little shop of horrors is light years ahead as his best ever.
summary: that church in the movie is a tent revival

reviewText: "Leap Of Faith" jumps off the stage as a pentecostal hoe-down of a film, and the perfect vehicle to showcase what Steve Martin can do, given a challenging dramatic part..And boy howdy, does Martin deliver the good word!..Martin is akin to a lily white Michael Jackson in his prime, sequined jacket and all, sans glove..And more importantly, you won't want to miss a single frame of Martin, as Jonas Nightingale, the huckster "faith-healer" like a shark on the eternal prowl for sinners to sink his teeth into!..Martin and his holy-rollers end up stranded in Kansas because of truck-engine trouble, and pitch tent on the spot, to meet their expenses of $3500 a day..It just so happens this Kansas town is smack dab in the middle of a dustbowl drought, that has the bank recalling all the local farm loans, yikes!..Baby, they need a little rain, quick!..Will, the local badge, (Liam Neeson), sees right through Jonas and does everything within the law to defrock Jonas to keep the locals from pouring money they can't spare, into Nightingale's coffers..Jonas's manager, (Debra Winger) and Will find a little faith of their own, a sideshow..Jonas claims he's not a fraud, but just a straight up entertainment empresario, like the other Billy Graham of Fillmore West, producing a "Broadway" opus ala Godspell, and Jonas delivers the message everynight with a rheumatic fever, hotter than hell!..You just have to see Martin in action to believe your eyes, and you will walk away a true believer, if not in the false prophecies of Jonas Nightingale, then in the genuis, comedic gifts of Steve Martin..Are you ready for a miracle?
Title: N/A

reviewText: We know Steve best in comic roles, this one is more serious. reviewText: What I like most about this movie is its refusal to let any point of view win for too long.  Sure, Jonas Nightengale is a con man, but he puts on a great show that people love.  Many questions are raised by this kind of preacher-congregation relationship.  Certainly, this is not saying that all preachers or priests are con men (or is it?), nor is it implying that all religious believers are dupes, fools, or simply an audience watching a show (or is it?).One of the questions raised is whether the whole religious idea is all just a scam, as Jonas Nightengale embodies it.  Obviously not, but it is also true that this kind of scam has a long tradition (read the Canterbury Tales) and continues in full vigor today.  The next question is whether the insincerity of the preacher invalidates the faith of the believer.  Again, obviously not.  However, are believer often too gullible?  Absolutely.This movie is populated with all kinds of believers, non-believers, scammers, scam - enablers, doubters, and more.  It is interesting how each of their stories comes up against what Nightengale represents.  In some ways he is a screen onto whom they project their doubts, fears, hopes, and dreams.  Is that what religion is?  For some, maybe.  However, I think that such an explanation is really more attractive to non-believers than a real explanation of how religion functions in the lives of believers (not just audiences of folks who are just religious attendees).The movie does raise the issue of what happens when real belief - actual faith - runs into the scam.  I cannot divulge the end of the movie, but it isn't pat in its answer.  You can explain it according to your own lights.  As a believer, I have a certain view of what the story is getting at.  But the story really is more about raising questions to think about rather than trying to insist on a viewpoint of belief or rejection of belief.  It even looks at why people might choose to believe or not based on reasons that actually have nothing to do with questions of faith.The lack of an easy answer to what the movie is about might bother some, but I think it makes it more meaningful for most people.  For people of faith, some aspects of Nightengale's scam will feel like the blaspheme they are, but I would urge them to be patient to see where things lead.  Remember the story of Saul leads to Damascus by way of the martyrdom of Stephen.  No, Nightengale does not become Paul, but just wait.
summary: Raises questions to consider rather than creating doubt.

reviewText: I have never particularly enjoyed Steve Martin as an actor, but bought this film because based upon the description, it sounded like he was made for the role. Was he ever!Often where that's the case the supporting cast is weak, but not here. This is one of those rare cases of nearly perfect casting.If you enjoy traditional gospel music, or even if you generally don't, you will love the musical support provided by the Angels of Mercy (including La Chanze, Delores Hall and Albertina Walker) who are superb as Jonas's choir.There is none of the unpleasant ridicule of evangelicals (I am not one) that often characterizes films of this type. This is one where everyone comes out smelling good. Truly uplifting.

reviewText: What a great film.  A spellbinding performance by Steve Martin, who seemingly was born to play this role.  He portrays Jonas Nightingale, a traveling huckster of a preacher, who leads an entourage going from town to town bilking poor hopeful people out of what little they do have.Another reviewer was dead on - it is impossible to watch any of his scenes in this film without focusing totally on him. He is so full of the role but not in an overbearing way (unlike Jim Carey whose portrayal as Batman's foil The Riddler, comes to mind as a poor comparison).It's not merely a send up of preaching, Christianity or of films like the great Elmer Gantry (to which it is often compared and found severely lacking).  It is much more than that.  It is also much much lighter.  It also has a brilliant musical score, dominated by some of the most stirring and uplifting gospel music ever to come from any of God's creations.Different from any role Steve Martin ever did.  Brilliant!
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I was a kid, my favorite movie was "The Music Man". I must have seen it in the theater at least a dozen times. I loved the story of the con man who got caught in his own con and I experienced the same joy watching Steve Martin do his own version of Prof. Harold Hill (now Jonas Nightengale) in "Leap of Faith."This movie was truly misunderstood by most critics who tried to compare it -unfavorably- with such films as "Elmer Gantry" or characterize it as a statement on televangelism. They also focused too heavily on the emotional, and therefore, "unrealistic" ending. Even worse, the studio mis-marketed the film, and you'll often find it in the comedy section of the video store. Warning: it is not a comedy. Yes, there are light moments- how can there not be with Steve Martin- but this film is much richer than a typical Steve Martin comedy.Steve Martin's performance is superb and magical and should have been nominated for an Oscar. The film score is tremendous with some of the best gospel singers in the country providing the music- not to mention Meatloaf! Contrary to the critics, I found the ending mesmerizing- left open enough for interpretation, moving, and inspirational.So, ignore most of the critics, approach it with an open mind, and be willing to listen to the message. "I always think there's a band, kid," said Harold Hill in "The Music Man"; "Just because a person doesn't show up doesn't mean the person doesn't care about him," says Jonas Nightengale in "Leap of Faith". Enjoy!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had the unique opportunity to review scenes from this film a year before it was released. I was at a mall and got asked if I wanted to participate in an exercise involving film and desserts. I chose film. They lead me into a room and explained they were going to show me proposed preview from an upcoming film release, nothing more.So the film began and Leap Of Faith was the film.Afterward, they asked my opinion about the effectiveness of the preview and I told them it needed more information for the viewer as to just what the bloody thing was about. The preview was incomplete with regard to giving me a sense of the film's direction, or at least the basic elements of the plot.Potential spoiler here:Well, I later saw the film and fell in love with it because it was not so much about slamming tent "revivals" as much as it was about a huckster being "one upped" by God. The irony was quite wonderful.So I do recommend this because Steve Martin puts in a great performance that is in line with his more creative schtick. He was a great choice to play the lead for this reason... he really fits the "type", at least what we perceive as the "type" who would become such a person as the character portrayed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Steve Martin gives the performance of a lifetime, as con-man Jonas Nightengale, in this cynical comedy - turned drama - turned spiritually uplifting wonder of a film. If you haven't yet seen this movie, to quote the signature song performed by the Angels of Mercy, "Are you ready for a miracle?" What starts out as a darkly comedic expose' of a traveling bogus preacher and his entourage, turns into an uplifting affirmation of faith. I can't recommend this gem highly enough.Equal credit should be given to the supporting cast members, Lolita Davidovich, Debra Winger, Liam Neeson and Lukas Haas. I don't know why this movie didn't clean up at the Oscars, because it surely deserved to.

reviewText: What keeps me from giving this movie 5 stars is that it is uncomfortable. I would entertain that this might not be a good reason. It is uncomfortable to watch a group of swindlers take advantage of poor people. Rationalizations made by the lead swindler portrayed (excellently) by Steve Martin make some sense, but his attitude while he gives the rationalizations undermines the rational. Never-the-less, the finish to the movie requires some deep thinking and warrants conversation. (What is your take on the ending?) I should note that Steve Martin uses the same style of acting in "My Blue Heaven" - exaggerated - yet quite true and accurate to real life character.

reviewText: Steve Martin  plays a phony evangelist whose traveling roadshow unexpectably gets stuck in a small Kansas city. He's backed up by expert players: Debra Winger as his partner in crime, Liam Neeson as a cynical sheriff, Lukas Hass as a lost boy crippled by an auto accident that took his parents, Lolita Davidovich as his older sister, and Meat Loaf and Philip Seymour Hoffman as part of the evangelist's road crew. All underplay their roles, which keeps the movie from degenerating into a tear jerker or just another one of Hollywood's cynical takes on Christianity.Motives, good and evil, are exposed only to be laid waste by God's sovereignty. Martin's final words say it all.
summary: martin plays it from the heart

reviewText: Spoiler Alert: Leap of Faith ends with a huge does of hoaky. I mean overwhelming, old-school-Hollywood hoaky. What's worse, it seems like it was clearly integrated to satisfy members of the ballooning religious right of the early 1990s who otherwise would have been expected to dismiss the film as another lefty-depiction of hollow American Christianity.Up until that point, though, Leap of Faith is a wonderfully complicated and human film about hard-working showmen making the best of a bad situation. Liars using their skills of deception to make bits of good happen in the world -- and loads of money fall into their pockets. Until those liars discover that, despite their best efforts, they've managed to tap into something true and create something absolutely real. That paradox is as old as time but rarely has it been explored with as much fun or honesty as this film. Again, until the unnecessary, cheap, and hoaky ending.Steve Martin gives one of his strongest performances here (though his in-revival stage dancing seems a bit too clownish, it's so much fun and he fills the scenes with such presence it's hard to take issue). Neeson doesn't have much to work with, and he seems to only half-heartedly embrace an American accent (sometimes he seems to drop it all together), but he's likable and he and Winger's chemistry is quite fun to watch.Meatloaf is underused but it's fun to see him on screen. The real joy for me, and why ultimately the film get's a 4/5 instead of a 3/5 despite the ending and Neeson's accent, is watching an early-20s Philip Seymour Hoffman, particularly in light of his late passing. He has a blast with his small role, and lights up the screen every time he's in frame. He also isn't given much to do here, and at the time the film was released it would probably have been easy to overlook. But watching one of our greatest artists sprout in early roles like this helps ease the pain of his loss.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Leap of Faith is Hollywood's take on the disturbing subject of 'stealing in the name of the Lord', the lowest form stealing.  It's understandable why Christian believers would not want any part of seeing this movie.... but than again, they should be the first to see it as it's premise is nothing new and in no way maligns or mocks their faith, rather, the film is a commentary about fake evangelists and faith-healers out for a buck.  The Gospels record such goings on in the first century when Jesus ran everybody out of the temple for turning it into "a den of robbers".  OK so the acts were different but the idea is the same: preying on those in need and on their vulnerabilities.  In the temple, it was people who came from all over to make sacrifices to atone for their sins, and with bogus evangelists and faith-healers it's their need for salvation and healing.Steve Martin does a wonderful job at pulling off the heartless con man who cares nothing about the people in a town that has fallen on hard times particularly because of an extended drought.  As I stated before, the movie is not jab at Christianity.  If anything, it defends it as it makes commentary not only on this bogus faith-healer but also how God - as He does in the pages of the Bible - can take any situation and use it to His Glory and to the benefit to those who believe.  In this movie a real miracle takes place that upstages the players.  Through the efforts of corrupt sinners preying on sinners looking for help, God is totally in control to bring a blessing and even make the preying one take note.  To quote Joseph "What you meant for evil, God meant for good".  All in all, we are all in the same boat - sinners needing salvation, not only from Hell but also from our own ways that cause us and others pain and suffering and what a way God chooses to bless humanity not only to allow Himself to become one of us via His Son Jesus but also through humanity itself regardless of the condition.The movie concludes wonderfully as we find our preacher man having repented and the town is once again blessed.... Rain!

reviewText: A movie I had the pleasure to experience a few years back when it hit the cinemas, and I was excited to see it as part of the Amazon Prime selection.Steve Martin showed his quality acting skills in yet another of his stellar serious type roles. Debra Winger was a solid supporting actress, but Liam Neesen let me down a couple times when he drifted somewhat out of character. The overall plot angle of the movie was engaging and stayed interesting. There were a few moments where filler material seemed to fill minutes in the storyline, but overall the story maintained a consistent course of direction and was enjoyable.The ending may leave some wanting for more in-depth explanations of a few of the plot angles, but I felt like it closed the door satisfactorily all the while placing a moral to the story type of ending.

reviewText: A traveling preacher (Martin) struggles with faith in God because of earlier circumstances in his life. He has developed a cynical, manuipulative "ministry" of healing. He pulls into a small town, not his usual type of turf and meets an injured young man with lots of faith and his older sister who is in many ways like Martin. Tensions mount. A surprise ending. I enjoyed this movie very much. I recommend it for those wholike stories of redemption.

reviewText: Christians stayed away from this movie when it was released. They should not have. For Steve Martin is not spoofing God or Christianity, but the absurd idea of putting Faith in a walking carnival of a Minister who claims to hear repeatedly from God. It is the blind leading the blind. The irony of it is that as much as the Church objects to Hollywood, it was Hollywood that made a movie pointing out what Christians refused to speak out on. Steve Martin watched hours and hours of tv evangelists before creating this film. He told his wife that these guys were better actors than anyone in Hollywood. The fact that the film features more than one answered prayer makes me think that God wanted this movie made. As Christians didn't want to do it, God recruited Steve Martin.
summary: I wonder if Benny Hinn has seen this?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm surprised this movie is not held in higher esteem by the public and critics.  A perfect role for Steve Martin who plays an over the top con man minister trying to score on the local waitress.  When the bus breaks down he decides to open a revival and and put some time in the effort.But this farming town is in the depths of depression caused by a drought.  Martin deserved an academy award for his brillant portrayal.  Great supporting performances by Debra Winger, Liam Neeson and Philip Seymour Hoffman in his first memorable role.The other star of this movie is the excellent score particularly near the end as the author shifts from the con to "could this be real".  Not often is the score so prominent in manipulating thre viewer emotionally.  I'm agnostic but the story is so uplifting that you can't help but be touched.  Also the sweeping scenes of middle Americans is very inspiring in projecting average Americans going about their lives.This movie entertains and mentally challenges the viewer.  I score this movie very highly and a must see particularly if you enjoy watching the career journey of the brillant Steve Martin.
summary: Brillant backed by uplifting music score

reviewText: Here is a role one never expects Steve Martin to portray. It's not really comical, it's actually a cynic's playground and Martin plays the worldly cynic to a tee. As a stereotypical "slick, used car salesman" of a revival preacher, Martin does the job. He takes his "traveling circus" of a religious TV evangelist on wheels for a spin in a town low on faith, hope...and rain. Set in the drought-plagued plains this movie really works.
summary: Leap into Faith...(or faithlessness as the case may be)

reviewText: I first saw this in a VHS format, and the primary comment is that the Widescreen view, and 5.1  audio is very good. So, if you have seen this film, think you know it, well, please give it a second chance in its new life.Okay, my understanding on the basis for this film, is that it was written after a very prominent preacher was  caught doing exactly what Jonas does. This preacher is STILL very prominent. Anyways, the best drama is often based in fact. And the elements that make this drama work are  all  here, including the "Cold Reading" of the Policeman who pulls over the Main Truck in the opening scenes. It takes quite a skill to do the kind of cold reading that "Jonas" does, but it's more of an illusionist sort of trick, and for the most part makes great theatre, and in part is what some good side-show  Psychics do to "tell fortunes".Where this parts company with the real life Con men who pretend to be men of god who  have a line to God, is that Jonas discovers a real miracle with the Young Lukas Haas. Jonas Knows he is a fake, and justifies his work as someone who entertains at rates cheaper than the Stages in New York... entertainment at a reasonable price. So Jonas discovers that there is a real version of what he is selling, and he makes a break for it, and his miracle is complete with  the last few events of the film.There is a lot to this film, and very worth a few watches. I am surprised no extras were included, but I guess if they showed up how the real major con-artists  work, then they may get "sued". Part documentary, part insight into illusion theatre, it is defnitely a major drama piece, with great plots working on all fronts.
summary: Excellent Fare, and a Great Drama

reviewText: Steve Martin is born to play the starring role of Jonas Nightingale, a travelling huckster, fraud of a faith healer, demon "caster outer", "slay in the spiriter" & more importantly, a money grubbing false prophet. Along with his no-nonsense sidekick manager, Jane, played aptly by Debra Winger, they bilk poor souls  from a small town out of their hard earned cash with the oldest profession in the world. No, not prostitution.  The selling of the Gospel Of Jesus Christ!This film exhibits many word-faith doctrines such as "positive confession", "gospel of health", "gospel of wealth" and the whole "name it and claim it" belief. More imporantly, what it also has is some great smaller role performances given by Lolita Davidovich as waitress Marva, Lukas Haas as Boyd, Liam Neeson as Will, Philip Seymour Hoffman as Matt, and MEATLOAF as Hoover!This movie also has a great soundtrack with samplings from Don Henley, Patti LaBelle, Wynonna Judd and of course, the great Meatloaf with "Paradise By The Dashboard Lights"!Seriously though... This film has a great ending and shows what REAL MIRACLES are made of and EXACTLY where they are made...A fun & entertaining family film!Happy Watching!
summary: The Well Known Correlation Between MEATLOAF & Word Of Faith!
